newsitem.title: HONG KONG: HK's Tung gave donation to Britain's Tory Party.
newsitem.headline: HK's Tung gave donation to Britain's Tory Party.

text.p: Hong Kong's future leader Tung Chee-hwa, who plans to ban foreign donations to political parties when Hong Kong returns to Chinese rule in July, gave money in 1992 to Britain's Conservative Party.
"Yes, it is certain, Mr Tung himself has said so," an information officer with Tung's office said on Saturday.
The South China Morning Post reported on Saturday that Tung made a 50,000 sterling (US$81,500) donation to the Conservative Party before Britain's general election in 1992.
"This is a fact well-known to everybody and, as a result, I am particularly sensitive that this should not happen in Hong Kong," Tung was quoted as saying.
A Tung aide told the newspaper Tung had made the donation in a personal capacity when he was chairman of shipping group Orient Overseas (International) Ltd.
He resigned from that position last October to vie for the territory's future leadership post.
Last week Tung proposed curbs on civil liberties, including a blanket ban on foreign funding for political groups, to take effect after Britain hands Hong Kong back to China on July 1.
Tung's donation provoked heavy criticism from Hong Kong's pro-democracy supporters.
"It is ridiculous that he is now banning people from doing what he himself has done before," Cheung Man-kwong of the Democratic Party was quoted in the report as saying.
